instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> e2015)

The machine looks like a new one, not even scratched, 17 cycles on battery, no signs of spill or previous repairs anywhere, board is spotless. It was dead when it came to me, no response on anything. Initially it had 8.6V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and S3/S0 rails were pulsing from 0V to high once in about two seconds. When I was taking measurements and inspecting the board under microscope, it even randomly (after reconnecting the charger to measure something) turned on twice, booted to OS and worked well until I turned it off. But one day later (without any repair attempt, just inspecting the board under microscope and measuring power lines) PPBUS dropped to 8.17V and S3/S0 pulses disappeared.
I thought <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> is gone, so I changed it for a new one. At once I also changed <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> (although there was no good reason to change it... I know), but that did not solve anything, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still lower than it probably should be. I did not find any shorted rail. Charger is genuine Apple 29W, USB-C cable is in good condition, works well with other <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>'s that I've got here. Connector and flex cable is also tested/good.

I'm not yet experienced with these boards and their design is quite different than the older ones, so I'm quite clueless... Even the schematics are worse than they used to be I think - I don't even understand how AON is produced.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.17V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> 3.23V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_E85_SS</SIGNAL> 14.41V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.28V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.28V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.28V

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0V, so all S4/S3/S0 rails are low

Thank you for any advice

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> dead, no <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>
threads.message: This is a common issue with these boards and I have no idea what is causing it. Have a few with the same issues here too. For now these go in the "some day" pile.
